name: esterification of vegetable oils and animal fats, average mix | glycerine | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24671/documentation

This dataset represents the production of the Brazilian average mix of vegetable oils and animal fats methyl ester, and the respective glycerine. The fatty acid methyl esther is produced by the reaction of oils and fats with an alcohol and catalysers. ;Data was obtained under the scope of the National Biofuel Policy (RenovaBio), implemented in 2017 by the Brazilian Federal Government seeking to expand the share of biofuels in the energy mix. On its framework, biofuels producers are subjected to a certification process, which requires Life Cycle Inventory data collection used to calculate the environmental efficiency (climate change category) of its product. Until the present study, 19 biodiesel producers have been certified and their LCI data are used in this dataset for describing the esterification process. All producers report using the methylic production route (i.e. methanol) and base catalysers (i.e. sodium hydroxide and sodium methoxide).;For the certification, all information regarding the esterification process does not differentiate raw material sources (soybean, animal fat or other oils) because it represents better the producer’s practice. Therefore, the created dataset has different raw material inputs in the same process. The raw material share is set to represent the national average.;Fatty acids methyl ester production in Brazil has two major sources: Crude soybean oil and animal fat. In 2018, soybean oil represented 69.8 % and animal fat 16.2 % of the raw material market, while cottonseed oil was responsible for 0.9 % (ANP, 2019). Minor sources (13.0 %) include palm oil, peanut oil, sunflower oil, castor oil, canola oil, corn oil, used frying oil and other materials. In this dataset, the shares of soybean oil, animal fat and cottonseed oil are scaled up to represent 100% of the raw material mix (80.28% soybean oil; 18.65% animal fat; and, 1.07% cottonseed oil). Density of methyl ester = 0.88 kg/l.;This dataset was developed under the Cornerstone project, an initiative from the Brazilian Business Network on Life cycle Assessment (Rede ACV) in collaboration with ecoinvent to increase the quantity and quality of inventories that represent Brazil, through a thorough adaptation of the datasets. More information about this project is available in: redeacv.org.br/en/wg-database/.;References:;;;ANP (2019). Petroleum, Gas and Biofuels National Agency Statistical Yeakbook 2019. Available at: www.anp.gov.br/publicacoes/anuario-estatistico/5237-anuario-estatistico-2019. ;;;ANP (2020). Eletronic System of Informations – SEI. 

From reception of raw materials at the factory gate through esterification of vegetable oils and animal fat.

System boundary is at the esterification plant. The product is ready for regional transportation to fuel distribution points, where biodiesel may be blended with fossil diesel.
category: C:Manufacturing/19:Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products/192:Manufacture of refined petroleum products/1920:Manufacture of refined petroleum products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data representing the 2018 average. Water consumption estimated according to value reported in the ‘esterification of soybean oil’ dataset representing the global region for the year of 2009.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Typical vegetable oil esterification plant designed for the production of methyl ester (for use in the vehicle fuels market). All producers report using the methylic production route with base catalysers (i.e. sodium hydroxide and sodium methoxide).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Water consumption estimated according to value reported in the ‘esterification of soybean oil’ dataset representing the global region for the year of 2009, which is referred to soybean esterification plants from US. The uncertainty information was adjusted accordingly
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Primary data collected by 19 biodiesel producers in the framework of the RenovaBio policy. The data was retrieved from the RenovaCalc file of each producer, accessed through Electronic Information System (SEI) of the Petroleum, Gas and Biofuels National Agency (ANP, 2020). This dataset represents the average information weighted according to the production volume of each producer. For the RenovaBio certification, information regarding the esterification process does not differentiate raw material sources (soybean, animal fat or other oils) because it represents better the producer’s practice. Therefore, this dataset has different raw material inputs in the same process. The raw material share is set to represent the national average according to ANP (2019). All producers report using the methylic production route. Data collected for the 2018 production year.

Reference: 

ANP (2020). Electronic Information System (SEI). Available at: anp.gov.br/processo-eletronico-sei. Accessed in: 04/06/2020.

ANP (2019). Petroleum, Gas and Biofuels National Agency Statistical Yeakbook 2019. Available at: www.anp.gov.br/publicacoes/anuario-estatistico/5237-anuario-estatistico-2019.

dataGenerator.name: F. Valebona; T. B. Rocha; F. L. Motta

Measured value. Weighted average of 19 biodiesel producers.

exchanges.description: Wastewater from process. Estimated according to soybean esterification plants from US. Value reported in the ‘esterification of soybean oil’ dataset representing the global region, converted from gallons to m³ and scaled to the the production of 1 kg of fatty acid methyl esther.

exchanges.description:
Calculated from the reported amount of diesel consumption in m³. The average biodiesel blend is 9%, however fossil diesel is used as a proxy for the whole mixture. Weighted average of 19 biodiesel producers.
Conversion factors from the Petroleum, Natural gas and Biofuels Brazilian National Agency (ANP):
Diesel density is 0.88 t/m³
Biodiesel density is 0.88 t/m³
Diesel lower heating value is 10100 kcal/kg
Biodiesel lower heating value is 9000 kcal/kg
